metadata.title: Micro-AlN/Nano-SiO2 Co-filled Silicone Rubber Composites with High Thermal Stability and Excellent Dielectric Properties

sections.text:
in neat form, it has low thermal stability and poor erosion resistance which restricts its outdoor applications. In this work, we explored the high thermal stability and excellent dielectric properties of SR co-filled with micron-AlN and nano-SiO2. Samples of SR composites with different mixture (micro, nano and micro/nano co-filled) are fabricated by mixing techniques of mechanical stirring followed by sonication. Test results show that there is a significant escalation in the corresponding temperature of 5%, 25% and 50% weight loss. Besides, it is noticed a significant increment in residual percentage weight of the polymer component of co-filled composites. Moreover, co-filled composites show no major variations in the real permittivity but they offer lower dielectric loss relative to AlN30m. AlNmn3 and AlNmn4 are found to be the most promising co-filled composites for high thermal stability and dielectric properties, respectively, which makes them suitable for electrical insulation purposes. Keywords: Outdoor insulation; Polymers; Thermal stability; Dielectric properties; Nanoparticles; AlN & SiO2.
* Author for correspondence (muhammadtariq.nazir@unsw.edu.au)
1. INTRODUCTION
Over the past four decades, silicone rubber (SR) insulators have been increasingly considered owing to their superior or comparable physical, electrical and chemical characteristics as compared to traditional ceramic- and glass-based insulators. Lower weight, design flexibility and easy transportation and installation on field towers make them superior to conventional counterparts [1-3]. Among SR’s drawbacks are poor resistance against erosion, which arises due to successive dry band arcing, and build-up of high temperature zones on the SR surface. Hence, thermal stability is an important consideration as it significantly affects thermal aging and erosion of SR [4]. Previous studies reveal that inorganic oxides, nitrides and carbide fillers dispersed in the polymers enhance its thermal properties [5-10]. Kemaloglu et al [11] reported enhanced thermal properties of SR filled with micro and/or boron nitride nanoparticles and the particle size aspects on thermal and mechanical properties were explained. The effect of hybrid boron nitride with varying particle size on thermal conductivity and thermal stability was reported in [12]. Recently, the excellent dielectric, thermal and mechanical properties of SR with combined micro and nanoparticles have been reported [13].
AlN and SiO2 have high intrinsic thermal properties and electrical resistivity, respectively. To date, no studies have been reported on the thermal stability and dielectric properties of SR co-filled with micro-AlN and nano-SiO2 particles. This letter presents an investigation of the combined effect from such fillers on the thermal stability and dielectric properties of SR.
2. EXPERIMENT
Pristine liquid form of SR (parts: A & B) was obtained from DC Products Pty Ltd, Victoria, Australia. Micron AlN (particle size: 5 µm, density: 3.26 g/cm 3 ) was supplied by
Xuzhou Jiechuang New Material Technology Co., Ltd, China and nano-precipitated SiO2 (particle size: 20 nm, density: 2.6 g/cm3) was procured from Sigma Aldrich. Initially, the particles and part A were mixed with a mechanical stirrer for 5 minutes and then the matrix was evacuated. Next, sonication was carried out for 80 minutes in a water tank at 40 kHz frequency. Subsequently, part B was added at a ratio of 10:1 and mixed again as mentioned above. The procedure for fabricating the composites samples is described in detail in our previous publications [14]. A Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851 instrument was used for thermal stability studies. The sample weight was adjusted to approximately 12 mg for TGA analysis and temperature was ramped at a rate of 10ºC/min from 50ºC to 800ºC. The dielectric response was measured with a Novocontrol broadband dielectric spectrometer at room temperature over a frequency range of 10 2 to 10 6 Hz. The sample surfaces were prepared by hand cutting before scanning electron microscopy (SEM Hitachi S3400) was engaged for topographic surface imaging of the composites. Before performing dielectric spectroscopy and SEM imaging, all the samples were sputter coated with gold. The gold electrode diameter was fixed to 30 mm for dielectric spectroscopy.
3. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Table 1 shows the nomenclature and principal thermal stability characteristics of the composites investigated including the temperature for 5, 25 and 50 % weight loss of filled composites. It is observed the introduction of particles in SR results in remarkable enhancement of thermal stability. Figure 1 shows a selection of the thermal stability curves. Enhancement in the T5% and T25% can be seen for the nano-filled composites and, more significantly, in the co-filled composites comparative to the pristine rubber and micro-filled composites which generally show inferior values. The T5% of AlNmn1, AlNmn2.5, AlNmn3, AlNmn4 and AlNmn5 increases by 35 ºC, 53 ºC, 60 ºC, 35 ºC and 50 ºC in comparison to PR, respectively. Interestingly, no weight loss by 25 % or more is
observed in the co-filled composites until 800 ºC except AlNmn1. Furthermore, only unfilled PR lost 50 % weight below 800 ºC, at 717 ºC.
To make it more meaningful, the percentage residual weight of the polymer component of co-filled composites is compared with their total equivalent 30wt% micro AlN (AlN30m) filled composite as shown in Table 1 by assuming that weight loss occurred in the polymer component only due to substantially high melting and flash points of fillers. The residual weight of polymer component of co-filled composites (AlNmn1, AlNmn2.5, AlNmn3, AlNmn4 and AlNmn5) is enhanced by 34%, 47%, 52%, 47% and 49% with respect to their equivalent 30wt% (AlN30m). Furthermore, the thermal stability of polymer is not only dependent on particle loadings but also the interaction between polymer matrix and particles contributes as well as seen in the differences between different filler sizes.
Figure 2 shows the dielectric properties of the micro, nano and micro/nano co-filled composites at frequency of 1 kHz. From Figure 2a, it can be seen that the permittivity of micro-AlN filled composites increases with particle loading. This might be attributed to the significant polymerization at the AlN/matrix interface and depolarization of AlN particles [10]. Micro-filled and micro/nano co-filled composites exhibit higher permittivity values and this can be due to less restriction in the mobility of PDMS chains in micro and co-filled composites than in PR and nano-filled composites (Figure 2b). Permittivity and dielectric loss of co-filled composites are compared with their total equivalent 30wt% micro AlN (AlN30m) filled composite (Figure 2c) and reveals no marked variations except for AlNmn5. The permittivity of AlNmn4 is found marginally lower than AlN30m. A sharp decrease in the dielectric loss can be noticed in AlNmn4 which is remarkably lower than 0.0015.
Hence, micro-AlN/nano-SiO2 co-filled system results in higher thermal stability, excellent low relative permittivity and dielectric loss. Besides, such striking results make
SR superior over micro-composites used for outdoor insulation where the filler loading requirements are substantially high from industrial perspectives.
Figure 3a shows the morphology of the AlNmn4 samples and exemplifies that both sizes of particles are distributed uniformly in the composites. With increasing nano-SiO2 loading, the nano-fillers fill in the regions between micron-AlN particles in the co-filled composites and function as a bridging link between the micron-AlN and base SR as shown in Figure 3b. This introduction of nano-particles sharply reduces the inter-particle distances and amplifies their total surface area due to increased number of contents in the composites [15]. It can thus be anticipated that a closely-packed structure, achieved by covering the gaps between micro-AlN with nano-sized particles, may enhance thermal stability. Another possible explanation for the enhanced thermal stability and dielectric properties is better interaction of the particles with the SR matrix. Furthermore, FTIR spectra of AlN and SiO2 show the presence of hydroxyl groups on their surface and it can instigate the hydrogen bonding among particles and PDMS as shown in Figure 3c [14, 16]. It is believed that such bonding interaction leads to a reduction of mobility of PDMS chain at the interface of the particles and the SR which can enhance barrier resistance and thermal stability.
4. CONCLUSIONS
A significant enhancement in the thermal stability of silicon rubber is achieved through the addition of a mixture of micron-AlN and nano-SiO2 particles to create a co-filler composite. The enhancement is greater than that achieved through solely 30wt% micro AlN (AlN30m) filled composite. This is confirmed through increase in temperature for 5% weight loss and increased residual weight in TGA analysis. Dielectric properties are also affected by the inclusion particle fillers. Real permittivity increases with filler content, irrespective of the particle size and co-filled composites showed no major variations in
permittivity with respect to micro and nano-filled composites. Moreover, co-filled composites offered low dielectric loss values. It is perceived relatively lower than 0.0015 in AlNmn4 which is certainly convincing from electrical insulation point of view.

metadata.abstractText: Silicone rubber (SR) is the most promising polymer for outdoor insulation but in neat form, it has low thermal stability and poor erosion resistance which restricts its outdoor applications. In this work, we explored the high thermal stability and excellent dielectric properties of SR co-filled with micron-AlN and nano-SiO2. Samples of SR composites with different mixture (micro, nano and micro/nano co-filled) are fabricated by mixing techniques of mechanical stirring followed by sonication. Test results show that there is a significant escalation in the corresponding temperature of 5%, 25% and 50% weight loss. Besides, it is noticed a significant increment in residual percentage weight of the polymer component of co-filled composites. Moreover, co-filled composites show no major variations in the real permittivity but they offer lower dielectric loss relative to AlN30m. AlNmn3 and AlNmn4 are found to be the most promising co-filled composites for high thermal stability and dielectric properties, respectively, which makes them suitable for electrical insulation purposes.
